documents.title: derby centre : 'less people in city are being radicalised '
text: the derby pakistani community centre has called for more to be done to understand why young muslims are vulnerable to being radicalised by extremist groups .
shokat lal is from the centre said there is `` nothing normal '' about extremist behaviour .
he also believes there has been a reduction in the number of people being radicalised in the derby area .
he said this is because extremist groups used to be able to recruit on the streets - handing out leaflets and approaching young muslims .
he said you do n't see this anymore .
he admits that the internet has allowed it to go `` underground '' and vulnerable people are being `` groomed '' online instead .
author: Amy Woodfield

documents.title: indian soldiers to be remembered in special ceremony
text: look at these two war memorials .
the one on the left is in leicester , and the one on the right is in the indian city of delhi .
similar right ?
that 's because - apart from the fact the one in delhi is double the size of leicester 's - they were both designed by english architect edwin lutyens .
today leicester 's memorial will be visited by the high commissioner of india .

he is expected to attend a special commemorative event to lay a wreath of marigolds at the arch of remembrance in memory of the 1,174 indian men from the labour corps who lost their lives in world war one .
about 300 schoolchildren , as well as the city and lord mayors of leicester , will attend the ceremony .
it 's part of the unremembered project , which has been organised by the big ideas company .

documents.title: ancient 330-year-old shoes found in nottinghamshire attic
text: a pair of children 's shoes dating back to the 17th century have been found at a house in nottinghamshire .
the artefacts are 330 years old and would have probably been strapped beneath fabric shoes in order to protect a child from the mess on the streets .
`` streets in the towns were filthy‎ , '' auctioneer charles hanson said .
`` animal , especially horse , dung and human effluent from chamber pots was usually thrown directly into the street . ''
the shoes are set to be auctioned next week and the guide price for them is £ 600 to £ 800 .

documents.title: former courtaulds factory staff 'lied to ' over closure
text: it 's been a year since the courtaulds factory in belper closed its doors with the loss of 320 jobs .
the hosiery firm said its closure was in part due to the collapse of british home stores ( bhs ) , who were a `` major customer '' .
however , former workers have questioned that claim .
the bbc has been catching up with some ex-courtaulds staff who have now been able to find other employment .
tracey barlow worked for the company for 36 years and was a union rep there .
she feels staff were `` lied to '' .
i have never seen in any company presentation the fact that bhs was holding us up as a business .
we 've not traded with bhs as a major customer for a long , long time .
they perhaps had the pretty polly brand and the aristoc brand but they were not the biggest player in the company as far as i could see . ''
three months ago , an industrial tribunal awarded former workers more than £ 1m between them after it found that staff had n't been properly consulted on redundancy plans .

defending its original response , courtaulds administrators rsm said in a statement : `` the underlying problem at courtaulds was that it was struggling to compete against producers from lower labour cost countries .
however , the loss from bhs was nevertheless an important contributory factor in the demise of the company . ''
we were also told bhs accounted for £ 3.4m of sales for courtaulds in the previous financial year .
meanwhile , despite the victory in that tribunal , the former workers are still waiting for the payout from the insolvency service .
author: Navtej Johal
East Midlands Today reporter

documents.title: watch : leicester hosts vigil for manchester attack victims
text: about 200 people came to town hall square last night to show their support and solidarity with the victims of monday night 's arena bombing and the wider city of manchester .
speakers from faith communities said a few thoughtful words , the most passionate from young student amaan muhammed , from darul uloom leicester - an islamic school in the city .
afterwards people were encouraged to add to a simple but colourful message chalked on the floor - leicester ❤️ manchester .

one youngster there told me her friend had been at the concert in manchester on monday night , and that the tragedy had `` hit close to home '' but she wanted to show that `` terrorists will never succeed in driving people apart '' .
i 've never seen such a wide group of faith , political and community leaders gathered together from our city and county .
a short , simple , heartfelt message of respect and unity .
author: Tim Parker
BBC Radio Leicester reporter
